In this exercise, we will examine how we can calculate the future value of our retirement. 

Let's get started!

Let's first list all the information the exercise text gives to us:

1. We will invest monthly over the next 30 years.

2. We will invest $800 into the stock and $400 into the bond accounts. 

3. The nominal interest rate on a stock account is 11%

4. The nominal interest rate on the bond account is 7%.

5. Once we join the accounts into a single retirement account, their nominal interest rate will be 9%.

6. The withdrawal period will be 25 years.

7. The inflation will be 4%.

Notice that we have inflation happening. Hence, we cannot use the nominal rates provided in the exercise text. So, we need to find the real effective annual rate considering inflation. We can use the Fisher equation to find the real effective annual rate (EAR) : $$\begin{aligned} \text{Real rate} &=\frac{\text{Nominal rate} + 1 }{1 +\text{Inflation rate}} - 1 \\[20pt] \end{aligned}$$

Now let's calculate the real rates for both accounts.

The real rate of our stock account is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real rate}_\text{ Stock } &=\frac{\text{Nominal rate} + 1 }{1 +\text{Inflation rate}} - 1 \\[20pt]
&=\frac{11\% + 1 }{1 +4\%} - 1 \\[20pt] 
&=6.73\% 
\end{aligned}$$

The real of our bond account is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real rate}_\text{ Bond } &=\frac{\text{Nominal rate} + 1 }{1 +\text{Inflation rate}} - 1 \\[20pt]
&=\frac{7\% + 1 }{1 +4\%} - 1 \\[20pt] 
&=2.884\% 
\end{aligned}$$

Our stock and bond investments are nothing more but simple **annuities**. Hence, we can use the formula for the future value of annuity to calculate the future values of our accounts: $$\begin{aligned} \text{FVA} &= P \times[ \dfrac{(1+r)^n−1}{r}] \tag{1} \end{aligned}$$ Where: - P - Payment - n - Number Of Compounding Periods - r - Interest Rate ​
But before we can use Eq.$(1)$ to calculate the future value, we must first find the monthly rate. To find the monthly rate, we will divide the annual percentage rate by 12.

Recall that the annual percentage rate (APR) is calculated as: $$\begin{aligned} \text{APR} &= \Bigg(\Big(1 + \text{EAR}\bigg)^{\dfrac{1}{n}} - 1\Bigg) \times n \end{aligned} \tag{2}$$ Where: - EAR - real effective annual rate - n - Number of compounds in a year

Now to get the monthly rates, we divide the annual percentage rates (APR) by 12. The monthly rate of our stock account is: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Monthly rate}_\text{ Stock} &= \frac{6.530\%}{12} \\[10pt] &= 0.5441\% \end{aligned}$$ And the monthly rate of our bond account is: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Monthly rate}_\text{ Bond} &= \frac{2.846\%}{12} \\[10pt] &= 0.23716\% \end{aligned}$$

Now we can find the future values of our accounts by using Eq$(1)$. The number of compounding periods is 360 months (30 years).

Hence, the future value of the stock account is:

$$\begin{aligned}

\text{FVA}_\text{ Stock} &= \$800 \times  \dfrac{(1+0.5441\%)^{360}−1}{0.5441\%} \\[10pt]
&= \$889,980.74818

\end{aligned}$$

And similarly, the future value of bond account is:

$$\begin{aligned}

\text{FVA}_\text{ Bond} &= \$400 \times  \dfrac{(1+0.23716\%)^{360}−1}{0.23716\%} \\[10pt]
&= \$227,040.87934

\end{aligned}$$

To get the future value of our final retirement account, we simply compute the sum of these two accounts:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Retirement Account Value} &=  \$889,980.74818 + \$227,040.87934 \\[10pt]
&= \$1,117,021.62752
\end{aligned}$$
